text:
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW.

PRINCE ALBERT, N.W.T., FRIDAY, JANUARY 18, 1884.

$2.50 A YEAR.

OBITUARY.

WILLIAM MACKEY, Factor H.R.C. Co.

Through the death of Mr. William MacKay, Factor, Hudson's Bay Company at Prince Albert, we have lost a man who was highly respected in the community and whose loss will be felt by all who knew him. Mr. MacKay was born in Scotland and came to Canada in 1860. He was a member of the Hudson's Bay Company for many years and was well liked by all who knew him. He died on January 17th, 1884, at the age of 50.

JAMES MACDONALD.

James Macdonald, of the town of Macdonald, has passed away. He was a prominent citizen of the town and will be missed by all who knew him. Mr. Macdonald was born in Scotland and came to Canada in 1860. He was a member of the Hudson's Bay Company for many years and was well liked by all who knew him. He died on January 17th, 1884, at the age of 50.

TERRITORIAL NEWS.

REGINA

From the Regina Leader.

Some signs of whisky were spilled last week, owing to some infirmity.

On Monday—New Year's Eve—the streets were crowded with people enjoying the festivities of the skating rink. Quite a number of them were in costume, and a very successful evening of healthy and jolly amusement was enjoyed.

CALGARY

From the Calgary Herald.

Mr. Graham, our Chief Commissioner, has been appointed to the position of Chief Commissioner of the Hudson's Bay Company. He will take up his duties immediately and will be responsible for the administration of the company's affairs in the district.

MISSISSAUGA

From the Mississauga News.

The Grand Central Restaurant (Old Woolworth's) has been opened and is now ready for business.

MEALS AT ALL TIMES.

Boots and Shoes

We claim to have the best assorted stock of boots and shoes in Prince Albert, and are selling at prices which defy competition.

CUSTOM WORK

Warranted and done at shortest notice.

REPAIRING

Repairing attended to.

WHITE AND RED COWS

Fifteen year old, heavy with calf. The above can be purchased by paying cash or by agreement.

BATTLEFORD

Large shipments of flour for the Indian Department are arriving from Prince Albert.

R.B. WAY

Post Office, Prince Albert, N.W.T.

EDMONTON

From the Edmonton Journal.

A public meeting will be held on Monday night for the purpose of considering the election of a mayor and council for the city of Edmonton.

MOOSE JAW

From the Moose Jaw Tribune.

There is a great excitement among the cattle ranchers in the district over the recent discovery of a new disease.

A well signed requisition has been presented to the government, asking him to allow himself to be nominated at the approaching election for the office of mayor.

EDMONTON

From the Edmonton Journal.

Night watchmen on Monday night.

Territorial newspapers are very plentiful at present.

Several self binders have been purchased in this settlement for delivery next summer.
CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by our Reporters.

Weather.

A slight shower of rain on Wednesday morning last.

An account of the last entertainment of the Y.M.C.A. & L.C., is crowded out of this issue, but will appear in our next.

We have been informed that Moore & Macdonald have entered into a large contract for flour and that they are not paying so much for grain.

An interesting communication about telegraphic messages was submitted to us by Mr. Smith, and we shall give it full space in our next issue.

Any person having a book, writing or other property lost at the British Empire's Post Office or Office House.

The following have signed notices in the Cordova Bay Life Association, failing due Jan. 31st, are requested to provide for the same on or before that date. J. W. E. Macleod, agent.

Erratum.

The obituary notice of Mr. George McKay on first page, for Rev. John McKeay, "Church of England Missionary," reads: Presbyterian.

The man who had a half day late this week working shorter hours than usual (Tuesday) was Mr. Johnson, on the plan of the new contractors, Mr. Graham, was without it. He has been early on Wednesdays.

In future, when Mr. Thomson arrives on Monday evening, the regular time, it will remain until Wednesday morning, thus giving us an extra day, which will be most convenient to the people.

Weather.

The thermometer readings at Prince Albert, as taken at Emmanuel College for the past week:

| Date       | Min. | Max. |
|------------|------|------|
| Friday     | 11   | 29   |
| Saturday   | 15   | 29   |
| Sunday     | 15   | 34   |
| Monday     | 17   | 31   |
| Tuesday    | 17   | 31   |

The following.

The collection connected with the Wesleyan church at the Lower Flats, held a social in the church, of which Rev. Mr. Sinclair was pastor. On Wednesday afternoon, Mr. Sinclair visited Prince Albert people went down and a pleasant time was enjoyed. Tea was served and the children's wishes were granted. One of the good things usually on such occasions was dispensed by the ladies to the guests. After dinner, Mr. Sinclair visited the woman who had been supplied, the intellectual part of the feast was opened by a sermon from Mr. Sinclair.

Sinclair. After which the choir from the Methodist Church of Prince Albert gave some selections, the music being arranged by Mr. Brown and Mr. Sinclair.

The Rev. Caleb Parker was then called upon and exercised his talent in a reading instead. He then read the District school district, with good effect. Mr. Waggott then delivered a humorous speech in the course of which he recited an original poem written by himself. The poem was well written and the reader must feel them all, and an original composition of his own on the Law of labor, which was very favorably received. The Rev. Mr. Sinclair said: "I will remember you," so acceptably as to be kindly answered. All the members present joined in the chorus.

Johnson and Horace Hard was the next piece which was finely sung. Mr. Jas. Johnson sang a solo, followed by a song from Mr. J. H. Johnson. "Jack's Yarn," accompanied by Mr. Jas. Johnson, was very well sung. Mr. Jas. Johnson sang a solo, followed by a song from Mr. J. H. Johnson. "Jack's Yarn," accompanied by Mr. Jas. Johnson, was very well sung.

While by conversation the other day with an old resident of the North West, the subject of ending was touched on, and he said that he thought that the main game, as it fell out, probably the first ending match in a North West settlement, October, 1856, by the party of H.R.C. officers, was played at the Convent, while waiting at the Base En campment at the junction of the Louis St. Charles and Red River Rivers. The players were composed of the following gentlemen: Alex Simpson, author of the book on the North West; Mr. Donald MacTavish, brother of the late Governor MacTavish; Roderick Fiddes, the late Judge; Mr. Steele, the present owner of the court; Mr. Steele, one of the managers of the Pigot Sand Co.; John MacLaren, afterwards killed in a battle with the Indians near Fort Nelson, Alaska; W.N.G. Spencer, our informant, then in the H.R.C. Co., employed making the stone pipes, and others whose names this occasion may have escaped me on the bench of the grave.

Prince Albert, Sask.
The Boy Talks About Santa Claus—Book the Grocerman up on Fireworks.

"Hey, what did you get from Santa Claus?" asked the grocerman of the boy, as he handed him the grocery with a big blue necktie, on which was pinned a piece of beef, and a little tin containing a diamond.

"Santa Claus must have remembered you splendidly," and the grocer man handed the boy a sour orange.

"Dad said Santa Claus was Santa Claus," said the boy, "he let him hang around, and then went to the vinegar barrel and drew some vinegar in a glass and took it away with a secret smile, taste it and say it's orange."

"Do you know I wonder that there is a boy in this whole world that does not put up his firework fires when they have their parents bring them to their first seven years of their lives about Santa Claus? There was a child once who said it was wicked, and the grocer found out that his parents have been lying to it about the Santa Claus business. But you know, Santa Claus used to come down chimneys, and when I asked how a fat fellow would come down through a chimney, he would go through a stove pipe, pa would tell me that Santa Claus was made of India rubber, and that he could squeeze himself down any way, that didn't get anything made a change in the Christmas tree business for our church. You see, there have been a lot of people who have been children together the night before Christmas, and seeing a Christmas tree, and it is cruel on the old children. When the parents put expensive presents on the trees for their children, and the poor children stand there whimpering for a corn ball or an orange. The poor children began to think Santa Claus showed particularity, and the poor employed of the rich folks, and they were obliged to get something on Santa Claus, but this time me and my chum sold all the presents we got, and bought a whole lot of nice things for the poor boys, and when the chums began to distribute the presents, and find that the boys that months made up for popcorn balls, and they got ice skates and fur caps, and nice things, matters of course, the minister was afraid the church would be pulled as a disorderly house. I never had so much fun in my life, I'd like to see those poor boys happy in the seats. All I have got left is this necktie and almost diamond, but the fireman has made me a forty-five diamond, and it bright to me though it was the holiest. Do you know what a holiest is? It is the holiest thing in the world."

"That's a good boy," said the grocer man, as he shaded his eyes to look at the bad boy, and then he thought of the fireman's song, he said, "It's half a crown."

"But there is one thing I want to talk to you about. I saw you jump on a house to save the firemen from the fire at the fire last night, and your pa said you was hanging around the engine house a good deal, and I thought maybe that. Those firemen are pretty tough, and you will be spoiled if you go with them. You will be doing nothing to do with them, or you will bring yourself a gray hair in sorrow to the grave. Fire men are hard to hang around."

"When was this that firemen were hard citizens?" asked the boy indignantly.

"They are just as good citizens as you are," said the grocer man, "but they hang down collar, from the keystone barrel what do you do? Do you go down collar and put on a suit? No, you don't. You grab your fireman's pith helmet tight, and the firemen come and they go tight through your soldered belt hole burning kerplunking, and you sit there, and you are overcome by the smoke, when their partners draw you out by the legs, and others pull off their coat and pull you up the flight until your property is saved, and when you come back and kick because they stop you, they say, 'We're here to save lives and women and children.' Do they do it for nothing? No, they do it for $75 a month, and you pay that to the man who drives your grocery wagon. There isn't a man who gets as much salary as a fireman."

PRINCE ALBERT
AN OLD JOKE.

Some of our citizens will be able to recall the little incident which is thus given in Chamber's Journal:

"At a clerical gathering in a certain town in New South Wales an old minister rose and said: 'We all understand with the scriptural injunction—this day every man is expected to do his duty.' As the meeting was about to break up, one of the dergymen spoke to the reverend lape-maker and informed him that the minister was from England. 'Shakespeare,' replied the old minister; 'that can't be, for I've never read Shakespeare.'

The audience had not improved much with its travel, however. It arose out of a warm discussion on a very grave theological point, and the minister started divining the old fellow's views six years ago, and occasioned some laughter at the time. A recent good man, in making upon the heretics the solemn obligations they were under to uphold the faith, exclaimed with great earnestness: 'I say, Mr. So-and-so, I believe that England expects every man this day to do his duty.' After the meet- ing, when the minister was leaving, he heard saying to another, 'That was a ridiculous kind of Brother.' 'Yes, sir,' was the reply; 'but I believe it was known that it was,'—saying of the Duke of Wellington.

(Sometime it will be said that even ministers commit historical blunders. It is not much to be wondered at that if poor ignorant editors should misquote scripture, or if a minister should be thought to be considered that very often their early education in the good book has been neglected. The following story is told of a joke played upon a western editor (United States of course) by a wag who sent him a copy of the Bible. The editor had never heard of it before and thinking it was a new publication he wrote that it was a romance in prose, but entered, but as a matter of history it is laughable.)

Advertising.

The Chicago Tribune, it is said, receives for a column of advertisements, $3,000 per year. The New York Herald received for its advertising space $65,724 and for its highest $38,000. The New York Tribune, for the lowest, $29,834, and for the highest $100,000. This paper it is stated, has never at a loss for advertisements to fill their columns. That is largely due to the prices charged by the Halfpenny press.

(This is slightly above the average charged by the Prince Albert Times and yet the people will complain of high rates.)

Must the something.

"Yes," the tall thin passenger admitted, "a crying baby is bound to wake But then the mother's voice calms it away and, when a human being is shuddered up and down on the loose end of a tough stick sufficiently, it's got to do something. If it can't, it's a case of hell." And the jury was only out two minutes, and came in with a verdict for the defendant.

A medical writer asserts that women are so constructed that they cannot jump. Just for the sake of argument, we should like to induce the doctor to a more accurate examination with his feet and close the door. Science doesn't keep everything yet.

PRINCE ALBERT, N.W.T.
A SINGLE HAIR.

What a little thing! A single hair is to look at; how insignificant, and yet what power there is in it! A hair has been cut off by death, and yet it is the cause of sorrow that has been pent up for years to break forth afresh, and the events of years will pass away.

A single hair from the head of a woman a man loves, will draw tears from his eyes, and make the earth quiver if it is attached to his heart at one end and to her dear head at the other. A single hair has been the means of breaking hearts, and tearing off the wrong collar of the wrong coat. There is something about a hair on a man's coat that seems to convey a meaning, a secret at once, and an explanation even, sets that hair right. And yet how easy it is for the woman who gets on a man's coat in a street car, at the theatre, or anywhere that women wear their hair loose. The air is full of it, and it is a great wonder that there are not more accidents on men's coats. A coat made of rough material is bound to catch hairs that are going to fall off, and women should realize that accidents will happen, but they don't. If hair was at all same color, much trouble might be avoided, but probably it never will be.

There is a man in Milwaukee whose life is now in peril because of a hair on his coat. He is a man who never thought twice of any woman other than his wife. He is blind in one eye, he has lost his hearing, his teeth are nearly all shot out, he is bald, with a fringe of carrotty hair down by his ears, and altogether a man who is likely to attract attention by his peculiarly handsome appearance. But his wife has an idea that he is a terror, and finally believed that he had been seeing another sight in the society of other women and he never comes home but she searches him for strangers' hair. The boys in the show bar, where he went, told her of his wife's jealousy, and it is a cold day when they don't put a female hair or two on his coat. His wife has always been so afraid that he had begun to look upon his profession as a joke, and so to keep his mind from this obsession he encourages her in her hair hunting, and believes it is the only enjoyment she has. Her jealousy has known her personality and when she goes to church the congregation glances at the poor man she sees if he has been picked. One day the girl had been to church, and when she came back to her chair and the hair reached to the floor, and it was greatly admired. The husband of the girl had been to church, and tried to secure one of those hairs, and after shadowing the minister for a moment, Saturday morning he got his hair, and the girl had been crying, and he rolled it up and put it in his pocket-book.

The next day she went to church with his wife after admonishing the hair in his coat, leaving about two inches of the end sticking out of his coat. He felt a solemnity about his hair, and he could see that hair, and she did. The minister was praying, and the hairless man looked among the people, and the hairless woman looked as though she would have given largely to the heathen if it had been possible. She knew that the worst done people looking, and the perplexities started out on her face. The minister finished through praying and the people raised their heads, and she thought there must be an end to all things, pulled at the hair again, and got it out. She looked at it, and it was about four feet of one hair in her lap, and she locked it up in a helpless sort of manner as though she could not understand it. Her hair was full of that hair, and as she knew she would have to get up with the congregation to sing, she pulled again, and then her heart sank within her. She had five feet of it, and yet there was no end.

She had heard that hair was very good for the stomach, and she had been foolish by putting a spool of black silk thread in his vest for her hair, but all that was useless. She had been told that it was an unnamable ache, and she pulled again and got another foot, and no end, and she knew that she must go to church, though she was afraid if she kept on pulling she would fill a full grown woman's hair store. She looked at the woman and noted every sign of confusion was on her, and as the minister read the hymn he looked at her and she looked at him looking at him. Just as they were about to rise and sing, she gave one last, lingering, impassioned pull, and the hair fell out of her hand and the rolled it up in her handkerchief and got up to sing; but her face was red, and she looked pale.

Before the service was over, the minister of the church had asked her handkerchief out of the pocket of her coat, took out the hair and laid it on the altar, and then asked her where she had got it, and she said she had got it on her coat where he had been to get his hair cut, and she had been to church with the subject of female hairs. She told him she would show him when she also got home; and she did. She showed him how she got it, and the husband was so solicitous after her health—telling her he was going to have her examined by doctors, examined by doctors, examined by doctors, that she thought she was insane—that she actually believed she had imagined all that she had experienced in church with the long hairless man, and she thought she was a maniacomaniac on the subject of long hairs and from that day she has never seen a hair on a coat, and she has never come near a church, and she has never gone into a house with a whole head of female hair on her coat, and the wife—who had such a narrow mind—would never see the hair. But those who saw her pull in that hair, as though she was going to church, will always remember how the sight of her husband was ravelling out inside.

PROSPECTUS OF THE Prince Albert Directory.

BUSINESS GUIDE.

It is proposed to issue a Business Directory for the town of Prince Albert and District of N.W.T., in a pamphlet form containing the names and addresses of each business establishment, (which is inserted at moderate rate) and a descriptive notice of each.

This directory will contain a history of Prince Albert, its present condition and future prospects, together with a statement of the resources of the district which will be ascertained for the District of Lorne, extent of acreage cultivated, number of acres per inch, population, number of years of settlement of district, and other useful information, written by a well known journalist.

About 500 or more minutes will be published (subject to the encouragement received) which will be distributed throughout the Dominion and the Mother Country.

It is hoped that by this means, benefit will result, not only to each individual business man, but to the district as a whole, which will become better known and appreciated both at home and abroad and a healthy enthusiasm encouraged among the people.

Price of advertisement, whole page, with notice on opposite page, 10¢; two pages, 6¢; single copies, 5¢.

NOTICE.

To Lumbermen and Others

Who are desirous of obtaining Permits to cut Logs, House Logs, Rails, Fence Posts, Cordwood, etc., and of Timber in the District of Prince Albert, North West Territories.

Permits will be granted to parties who submit complete plans of the rules and regulations of the Dominion of Canada, and of any trespassing on Crown Timber Lands.

Timber cut in any form without a permit, subject to the provisions of the law, as laid down in said Act, will be well treated and punished.

The public is requested to assist in preventing the wanton and reckless method of felling timber, contrary to the directions laid down in the foregoing Act. If no perceptible means will have to be taken by Legislative interference to arrest the destruction of the forest timber, it will be required to apply the local wants of the people who are only beginning to settle on the fertile prairies.

Parties claiming wood already cut on most side of the Red River between St. Paul and Chicago, will be called and settle dues at my office immediately. All claims with lists will be submitted to the minister and dealt with.

Any information with regard to the raising of claims, or dues chargeable on the same kind of timber, in accordance with the Act, will be cheerfully given by calling on me at my office, Campbell's Block, near east door of Main St.

J. D. WAGGONER,
Crown Timber Agent,
Prince Albert District, N.W.T.
October 31, 1883.

CORRESPONDENCE.

Recent Events.

Situated as we are now in the North-West, with the immense tract of new country that is still under development, and with the vast resources of the country yet to be explored, it may perhaps be excusable if our attention is not more directed to events, small and great, that have taken place elsewhere, on which we may take another, as they lie in the chain of history, the facts of which are now being written by the pen of the historian.

The natural laws, which is proverbial throughout the whole world, that Empire for the Mother Country, may perhaps plead as an excuse for calling attention to the recent events which have taken place in the East, and following one another with a rapidity totally unlooked for. It does not require the historian to show us that there was occurring in this land of Egypt with which we are so familiar from our earliest years, a movement of trade and commerce of such vast importance to our little Island, and our only outlet for the traffic in India, that it must have been felt in every part of the world. In these days of invention and electricity, the old way of doing things seems almost obsolete, and we scarcely be able to hold good, as the formation of the telegraph closed following upon the event, which has been so much to make way for its successor. Only a few months ago, when we heard that the telegraph had been successful in carrying news, it became necessary to dispatch a sum armed force to Egypt, where the Committee had been unable to reach the expedition as to the result, and some nations, more especially the French, with whom we are on terms of amity and alliance, neither gave us their support by word or deed, so great did they think was the importance of the discovery and application of the telegraph over the discussion of the factions of the so-called "High Priests" of India, who, with their eyes fixed on the future, the religious supremacy over millions of minds, the secret of the East. It is the same story into the Egyptian War, and the short but glorious war that was so successfully got through, and the result of which is now known, because they are not really things of the past, and well-known to all, though quite recent events. But what is the future? What will be the success of our mission to the north of Africa? What should be done in the north of Africa? What should be done in the north of Africa? What should be done in the north of Africa?
